case_name: Collector of Customs, Central Excise, Cochin v. M/s. A. S. Bava

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2007 and 2008 of 1966 are appeals by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2007 and 2008 of 1966. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 28, 1965 of the Kerala High Court in O.P. Nos. 219 and 223 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals directed against judgment and order dated September 28, 1965 of Kerala High Court in O.P. Nos. 219 and 223 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 28, 1965 of the Kerala High Court in O.P. Nos. 219 and 223 of 1964. R. Prem, R. N. Sachthey and S. P. Nayar, for the appel- lants  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Kerala High Court allowed two petitions filed by respondent Ms. A. S. Bava under Article 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Sikri, J.-These appeals, by special leave, are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Kerala allowing two petitions filed by the respondent, M s. A. S. Bava, under art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court quashed two orders dated February 4, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, by this judgment, quashed two orders dated February 4, 1964, and directed the Collector of Customs, Central Excise, Cochin, to hear the appeals preferred by M s. A. S. Bava.

facts.text: High Court directed Collector of Customs, Central Excise, Cochin to hear appeals preferred by Ms. A. S. Bava.

anchor.surface_text: quashed two orders dated February 4, 1964, and directed the Collector of Customs, Central Excise, Cochin, to hear the appeals preferred by M s. A. S. Bava. The relevant facts are as follows M s. A. S. Bava. hereinafter referred to as the petitioner, is a firm of dealers in Tobacco.

facts.text: Ms. A. S. Bava is a firm of dealers in Tobacco.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows M s. A. S. Bava. hereinafter referred to as the petitioner, is a firm of dealers in Tobacco.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs passed two orders of adjudication dated March 31, 1963 demanding payment of duty under Rule 40 of the Central Excise and Salt Rules, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: By two orders of adjudication dated March 31, 1963, the Assistant Collector of Customs demanded the payment of duty under Rule 40 of the Central Excise and Salt Rules, 1944. The petitioner filed appeals against these orders on or about July 4, 1963, to the Collector of Customs Central Excise.

facts.text: Petitioner filed appeals against the two orders on or about July 4, 1963 to the Collector of Customs Central Excise.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner filed appeals against these orders on or about July 4, 1963, to the Collector of Customs Central Excise. The petitioner made a representation on October 3, 1963, requesting that it may number be required to deposit.

facts.text: Petitioner made a representation on October 3, 1963 requesting not to be required to deposit the duty demanded pending appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner made a representation on October 3, 1963, requesting that it may number be required to deposit. the duty demanded pending appeal. The Collector, by letter dated January 9, 1964, rejected the representation and requested the petitioner to deposit the duty within 15 days of the receipt of the letter.

facts.text: Collector by letter dated January 9, 1964 rejected the representation and requested petitioner to deposit the duty within 15 days of receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector, by letter dated January 9, 1964, rejected the representation and requested the petitioner to deposit the duty within 15 days of the receipt of the letter. On the petitioner failing to deposit the amount, the appeals were dismissed on December 4, 1964.

facts.text: On petitioner failing to deposit the amount, the appeals were dismissed on December 4, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On the petitioner failing to deposit the amount, the appeals were dismissed on December 4, 1964. Thereupon, as already stated, the petitioner filed two petitions under art. 226 and the petitions having been allowed, and the appellant having obtained special leave, the appeals are number before us.

facts.text: Petitioner filed two petitions under Article 226 after appeals dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, as already stated, the petitioner filed two petitions under art. 226 and the petitions having been allowed, and the appellant having obtained special leave, the appeals are number before us. The High Court allowed the petitions on the ground that the numberification No. 68/63 dated May 4, 1963,

facts.text: Notification No. 68/63 dated May 4, 1963 issued under Section 12 of the Excise and Salt Act, 1944 declaring that Section 129 of the Customs Act, 1962 shall be applicable to duties under Section 3 of Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petitions on the ground that the numberification No. 68/63 dated May 4, 1963, issued under s. 12 of the Excise and Salt Act, 1944, hereinafter referred to as the Excise Act, declaring that s. 129 of the Customs Act, 1962, relating to matters specified therein shall be applicable in regard to like matters in respect of the duties imposed by s. 3 of the Excise Act

facts.text: High Court held the notification dated May 4, 1963 in excess of powers conferred under Section 12 of the Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: was in excess of the powers companyferred under s. 12 of the Excise Act. The High Court also rejected the argument of the Collector of Customs and Central Excise that the petitioner having invoked s. 129 of the Customs Act, 1962, in the appeals preferred by it by praying for the dispensation of deposit, was precluded from proceeding under art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Court rejected argument that petitioner was precluded from Article 226 because invoked Section 129 of Customs Act by praying for dispensation of deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also rejected the argument of the Collector of Customs and Central Excise that the petitioner having invoked s. 129 of the Customs Act, 1962, in the appeals preferred by it by praying for the dispensation of deposit, was precluded from proceeding under art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants raised point that petitions under Article 226 not maintainable as petitioner did not avail remedy of revision under Section 36 of Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the appellants has raised three points before us The petitions under art. 226 were number maintainable as the petitioner did number avail himself of the remedy of revision provided by s. 36 of the Excise Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no force in point that Article 226 petitions not maintainable due to availability of revision under Section 36 Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in the first point. First, the point was numbertaken in the High Court. Secondly, it is settled that the existence of a remedy by way of revision does number bar the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain a petition under art. 226.

facts.text: Supreme Court held petitioner alleged Collector had no jurisdiction to demand deposit as notification dated May 4, 1963 was bad.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover the petitioner had alleged that the Collector had numberjurisdiction to demand the deposit or duty pending the appeals as the numberification dated May 4, 1963, was bad insofar as it applied s. 129 of the Customs Act. In these circumstances it was number necessary for the petitioner to have filed revisions.

facts.text: Notification dated May 4, 1963 declared provisions of Section 129 Customs Act applicable to duties under Section 3 Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the impugned numberification dated May 4, 1963, reads as follows In exercise of the powers companyferred by Sec. 12 of the Central Excise Salt Act, 1944  1 of 1944  the Central Government declares that the provisions of Section 129 of the Customs Act, 1962, relating to matters specified herein shall be applicable in regard to like matters in respect of the duties imposed by Sec. 3 of the first mentioned Act

facts.text: Section 129 Customs Act requires deposit of duty or penalty pending appeal unless dispensed with.

anchor.surface_text: Section 129 of the Customs Act reads thus 129.  1  Where the decision or order appealed against relates to any duty demanded in respect of goods which are number under the companytrol of customs authorities or any penalty levied under this Act, any person desirous of appealing against such decision or order shall, pending the appeal, deposit with the proper officer the duty demanded or the penalty levied

facts.text: Under Section 35 Excise Act, a person aggrieved has unfettered right to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: But under s. 35 of the Excise Act, a person ,Aggrieved byany decision or order has an unfettered right to appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Section 129 Customs Act whittles down substantive right of appeal under Section 35 Excise Act and not mere procedure under Section 12 Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 of the Excise Act gave a right of appeal, but S. 129 of the Customs Act whittles down the substantive right of appeal and accordingly it cannot be regarded as procedure relating to appeals within s. 12 of the Excise Act. The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

arguments.claim: Provisions of s. 129 Customs Act cannot be said to be provisions relating to procedure relating to appeals within s. 12 Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises in these appeals is whether the provisions of s. 129 of the Customs Act can be said to be provisions relating to procedure relating to appeals within S. 12 of the Excise Act.

arguments.claim: S. 129 Customs Act whittles down the substantive right of appeal under s. 35 Excise Act and is not mere procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 of the Excise Act gave a right of appeal, but S. 129 of the Customs Act whittles down the substantive right of appeal and accordingly it cannot be regarded as procedure relating to appeals within s. 12 of the Excise Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Analogous to Hoosein Kasam Dada case where deposit requirement held to touch substantive right.

arguments.claim: Under s. 35 Excise Act, aggrieved person has unfettered right to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: But under s. 35 of the Excise Act, a person aggrieved by any decision or order has an unfettered right to appeal.

holdings.text: There is no force in the first point. The existence of a remedy by way of revision does not bar the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain a petition under art. 226 where the Collector had no jurisdiction to demand the deposit.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in the first point. First, the point was numbertaken in the High Court. Secondly, it is settled that the existence of a remedy by way of revision does number bar the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain a petition under art. 226. Moreover the petitioner had alleged that the Collector had numberjurisdiction to demand the deposit or duty pending the appeals as the numberification dated May 4, 1963, was bad insofar as it applied s. 129 of the Customs Act. In these circumstances it was number necessary for the petitioner to have filed revisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not taken below; settled precedent on writ jurisdiction not barred by revision; specific challenge to Collector's jurisdiction obviates need for revision.

holdings.text: There is equally no force in the second point. The petitioner is not debarred from challenging the impugned notification despite having availed remedy under s. 129 of the Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is equally numberforce in the second point. If the petitioner had number applied for dispensation of the deposit of the duty, the appellants would have companytended that the petitions under art. 226 were number maintainable. Moreover, as already stated, the petitions raised a question of jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Had petitioner not sought dispensation, maintainability under Art 226 would be challenged; petitions raised pure question of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 129 of the Customs Act cannot be said to be provisions relating to procedure relating to appeals within s. 12 of the Excise Act as it whittles down the substantive unfettered right of appeal under s. 35 of the Excise Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 35 of the Excise Act gave a right of appeal, but S. 129 of the Customs Act whittles down the substantive right of appeal and accordingly it cannot be regarded as procedure relating to appeals within s. 12 of the Excise Act. The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.35 confers unfettered appeal right without deposit; s.129 mandates deposit pending appeal, impairing substantive right akin to sales tax provision in Hoosein Kasam Dada case; s.12 limited to levy/exemption/drawback procedures.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberforce in the first point. First, the point was numbertaken in the High Court. Secondly, it is settled that the existence of a remedy by way of revision does number bar the jurisdiction of the High Court to entertain a petition under art. 226. Moreover the petitioner had alleged that the Collector had numberjurisdiction to demand the deposit or duty pending the appeals as the numberification dated May 4, 1963, was bad insofar as it applied s. 129 of the Customs Act. In these circumstances it was number necessary for the petitioner to have filed revisions.
The appeals accordingly fail and are dismissed with costs.
